questions.text: Which type of manoeuvre is depicted in the image given below?
questions.explanation:
Extended arms
  • Lovsets maneuver

Extended legs
  • Pinards maneuver

Aftercoming head
  • Dorsoanterior:
    • Burns-Marshall method
    • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique
    • Piper's Forceps
 
  • Dorsoposterior:
    • Prague maneuver
 
  • Aftercoming head of preterm:
    • Duhrssens incision

questions.text: A 28 year old woman with obesity spontaneously enters labour at 37+3 weeks gestation. Upon abdominal and vaginal examination, the fetus is found to be in a face presentation, with left mento anterior position. What is the correct pair of engaging diameter and/or presentation associated with this case?

options.label: D
options.text: Engagement of the head is not possible

questions.correct_answer: C. Fully extended head, Submentobregmatic 9.5 cm

questions.text: A 32 year old pregnant woman at 38 weeks gestation presents to the labour and delivery unit with regular contractions. On examination, the fetus is found to be in a persistent transverse lie. What happens if the patient undergoes a spontaneous vaginal delivery?
questions.explanation:
Bandl's Ring

Schroeder's Ring

Definition

An abnormal ring of constriction that forms in the uterus, typically between the lower and upper uterine segments. It causes an extreme form of uterine atony

A pathological ring of constriction that can occur in any stage of labor, resulting from oxytocin overuse, and may lead to uterine rupture

Cause

Prolonged second stage of labor

Oxytocin overuse, or misuse of uterine stimulants

Stage of Labor

Second stage of labor

Any stage of labor

Management

Cesarean section

Discontinuation of oxytocin, relaxation of the uterus (using tocolytics), and possible cesarean section depending on severity

questions.text: A 29 year old primigravida woman at 37+2 weeks gestation presents to the clinic for a routine prenatal visit. An ultrasound confirms a breech presentation. Given this scenario, which of the following is an absolute contraindication to attempting an external cephalic version?
questions.explanation:
External cephalic version (ECV):

Manipulations through the abdominal wall to achieve cephalic presentation.

Prerequisites:
  • Typically attempted before labour at 37 weeks gestation to balance fetal maturity risks and amniotic fluid volume.
  • ECV before 37 weeks may increase success rates but does not lower cesarean rates and raises late-term birth risk.
  • Spontaneous correction of breech presentation likely before 37 weeks.
  • Early ECV might allow reversion to breech.

Contraindications:

Absolute contraindication: Placenta previa or situations where vaginal delivery isn't possible.

Relative contraindications: Early labour, oligohydramnios, ruptured membranes, known nuchal cord, uterine abnormalities, fetal growth restriction, multiple gestations, prior abruption or risk factors.

questions.text: A 32 year old woman, G2P1, at 37+5 weeks gestation, presents to the labor and delivery unit for an attempted external cephalic version (ECV) due to a breech presentation. The procedure is attempted but ultimately unsuccessful. Given this scenario, what is the most appropriate next step in management?

options.label: B
options.text: Schedule an elective cesarean at 39 weeks

questions.text: A 28 year old multiparous woman at 39 weeks gestation arrives at the labour and delivery unit in active labour. She is confirmed to have a frank breech presentation. Which of the following is NOT a prerequisite for proceeding with assisted breech extraction?

options.label: D
options.text: The patient is kept hydrated orally

questions.correct_answer: D. The patient is kept hydrated orally

questions.text: Which perinatal outcome is more common in breech presentations than cephalic presentations, regardless of mode of delivery?
questions.explanation:
Category

Complications

Maternal
  • Increased risk of operative delivery (cesarean section or assisted vaginal delivery).
  • Increased risk of perineal trauma.
  • Prolonged labour.
  • Postpartum haemorrhage.
  • Pain and discomfort
  • Infection

Fetal
  • Umbilical cord prolapse.
  • Birth trauma, including head injuries (due to increased risk of head entrapment in vaginal delivery).
  • Hypoxic-ischemic injury due to cord compression or prolonged delivery.
  • Increased risk of birth defects or anomalies.

During Delivery
  • Shoulder dystocia (especially in breech extraction during vaginal delivery).
  • Delayed delivery of the aftercoming head (leading to potential birth asphyxia).
  • Increased risk of brachial plexus injuries.
  • Increased risk of fetal fractures (such as clavicle fractures).
  • Difficulty delivering the placenta (due to abnormal presentation).

questions.text: During a vaginal breech delivery, you encounter a case where one of the baby's arms is extended behind the fetal head, causing difficulty in delivery. What technique is used to manage extended arms in this breech delivery scenario?
questions.explanation:
Extended arms
  • Lovsets maneuver

Extended legs
  • Pinards maneuver

Aftercoming head
  • Dorsoanterior:
    • Burns-Marshall method
    • Mauriceau-Smellie-Veit technique
    • Piper's Forceps
 
  • Dorsoposterior:
    • Prague maneuver
 
  • Aftercoming head of preterm:
    • Duhrssens incision

questions.text: A primigravida at term presents with a breech presentation. The fetus has its thighs flexed on the abdomen, with the legs extended at the knees. What type of breech presentation is this?
questions.explanation:
Type

Characteristics

Complete (Flexed Breech)
  • Full flexion maintained.
  • Thighs flexed at hips, legs flexed at knees.
  • Presenting part: two buttocks, external genitalia, and two feet. (Option A)
  • Least common type of breech

Incomplete Breech

Varying thigh or leg extension degrees at the lower end (podalic pole). Includes three varieties:

  • Frank Breech (Breech with Extended Legs):
    • Thighs flexed on the trunk; legs extended at knees.
    • Presenting part: two buttocks and external genitalia.
    • M/c type of breech
  • Footling Presentation:
    • Thighs and legs partially extended, bringing feet to pelvic brim. (Option B)
    • High risk of cord prolapse
    • Vaginal delivery and ECV contraindicated
  • Knee Presentation:
    • Thighs extended, knees flexed, bringing knees to pelvic brim. (Option C)

questions.text: A 28 year old pregnant woman at 37 weeks gestation presents to the obstetric clinic for a routine check-up. On abdominal examination, the fetal head is not engaged in the pelvis, and the pelvic grip is empty. Fetal heart rate monitoring shows a normal baseline with reassuring variability. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

A 32 year old multiparous woman at 40 weeks of gestation presents to the labour and delivery unit in active labour. On vaginal examination, the fetus is found to be in a face presentation. Which of the following recommendations for managing labour in this patient can be true?

options.label: A
options.text: Manual conversion methods from face to occiput can be used

options.label: D
options.text: Elective C-section is done in cases of macrosomia

questions.correct_answer: D. Elective C-section is done in cases of macrosomia

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida at 37 weeks gestation is concerned about vaginal delivery due to congenital skeletal abnormalities. Examination reveals an obliquely contracted pelvis with a reduced anteroposterior diameter at the inlet, as shown in the image below. What type of contracted pelvis is most likely?
questions.explanation:
Type of Pelvis

Characteristics

Obstetric Implications

Naegele's Pelvis

 
  • It can be congenital or acquired.
  • Reduced anteroposterior diameter at the inlet due to one sacral ala being underdeveloped or absent.

Increased risk of difficult vaginal delivery; may require cesarean section.

Robert’s Pelvis (Option D)

 

Both sacral alae are absent, leading to a significant narrowing of the pelvic inlet.

Severe contraction often necessitates cesarean delivery due to significant narrowing.

Scoliotic Pelvis (Option B)

 
  • Asymmetry in the pelvic bones is caused by lateral curvature of the spine (scoliosis).
  • One of the oblique diameters contracts as a result of the pelvic asymmetry.

Variable impact on labour depends on the severity and specific characteristics of the scoliosis.

Kyphotic Pelvis (Option C)

 
  • Altered pelvic axis due to forward curvature of the spine (kyphosis).
  • The sacrum is narrow and straight, slanted backwards in the upper portion and forward in the lower half, and the subpubic angle is limited.
  • The anteroposterior diameter of the inlet is raised but is lessened at the outlet.
  • This complicates labour mechanics and necessitates cesarean section.

questions.text: A 30 year old woman, G2P1, presents in active labour at 40 weeks of gestation. Examination reveals the fetus is malpositioned at an occiput posterior position. If the fetus has a flexed neck and is of normal size, the maternal pelvis is adequate and has strong uterine contractions. What is the most likely outcome of the labour?

A 28 year old gravid woman at term comes to the labour room in active labour. Per vagina examination was conducted to identify the position of the head of the baby, and the baby was found to be in an occipito-posterior position. Which of the following statements is true about this position?

options.label: A
options.text: It always results in complete rotation of the head during labour

options.label: B
options.text: Seen with Android type of pelvis

options.label: C
options.text: Always presents with a well-flexed head

options.label: D
options.text: The occiput is near the pubic symphysis

questions.correct_answer: B. Seen with Android type of pelvis
questions.explanation:
Characteristics

Occipitoanterior

Occipitoposterior

Occiput position

(Option D)

Faces anteriorly to the pubic symphysis

Faces posteriorly towards mother's back

Facilitates NVD

Yes

No, it is usually associated with abnormal labour

Neck flexion (Option C)

Well flexed

Can be well-flexed, deflexed or partially flexed

Engaging diameter

Suboccipitobregmatic - 9.5 cm
  • Deflexed head: Occipito-frontal = 11.5 cm.
  • Incompletely flexed head: Sub-occipitofrontal = 10 cm
  • Well-flexed head: Suboccipitobregmatic = 9.5 cm.

Pelvis type (Option B)

Gynecoid and anthropoid

Anthropoid and android

Rotation during labor (Option A)

Complete rotation
  • Complete rotation
  • Incomplete rotation
  • Posterior rotation

Outcome of rotation

Direct occipito-anterior
  • Direct occipito-anterior
  • Occipito transverse
  • Persistent occipito posterior

questions.text: A 30 year old pregnant woman at 39 weeks of gestation presents for her routine antenatal checkup. During the abdominal examination, the following findings are noted: The abdomen below the umbilicus appears flat. The fetal limbs are palpated near the midline. The fetal back is palpated towards the right flank. The anterior shoulder is felt away from the midline. The fetal heart rate is best heard over the maternal right lower quadrant. What is the most likely fetal position in this patient?

A 30 year old pregnant woman at 40+5 weeks of gestation is planned for induction of labour with artificial rupture of membranes (ARM). Following ARM, a gush of clear amniotic fluid is noted, and a part of the umbilical cord is visible and pulsating upon vaginal examination, and the cervix is only 4 cm dilated. What is the most appropriate immediate management step for this cord prolapse?

options.label: C
options.text: Lift the presenting part off the cord and then proceed to cesarean section

questions.correct_answer: C. Lift the presenting part off the cord and then proceed to cesarean section
questions.explanation:
• Malpresentations:
    • Transverse
    • Breech (especially with flexed legs or footling)
    • Compound presentation
  • Contracted Pelvis
  • Prematurity
  • Twins
  • Hydramnios
  • Placental Factors:
    • Minor degree placenta previa with marginal insertion of the cord.
    • Long umbilical cord.
  • Iatrogenic Factors:
    • Low rupture of membranes
    • Manual rotation of the head
    • External cephalic version (ECV)
    • Internal podalic version (IPV)

Living baby

Definitive treatment

Cesarean Section (Best option for mature, living babies)

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Possible:
  • Head Engaged: Complete delivery with forceps (ventouse is less ideal).
  • Breech Presentation: Complete delivery by breech extraction.

If immediate Safe Vaginal Delivery Not Possible
  • Minimise cord pressure until definitive treatment or transfer to a suitable hospital.
  • Stop any ongoing oxytocin infusion.
  • Bladder Filling: Use a Foley catheter to fill the bladder with 400–750 mL fluid—empty the bladder before cesarean delivery.
  • Postural Treatment: Use an elevated Sims position with a pillow or wedge;
  • Cord Replacement: Place the cord back into the vagina to reduce vasospasm.

Baby Dead

  

Allow labour to proceed for spontaneous delivery.

questions.text: A 28 year old primigravida with a minor degree of cephalopelvic disproportion is being considered for a ‘trial of labour’. Which of the following is NOT a contraindication for the same?

A 26 year old primigravida comes to a tertiary hospital after being referred by a PHC. Examination reveals a minor cephalopelvic disproportion at the pelvic outlet outlet. The trial of labour shows non-progression of labour for 2 hours in the active phase. What is the next step of management?

options.label: C
options.text: Initiate manual rotation of the head

options.label: D
options.text: Continue trial of labour with close monitoring

questions.explanation:
Level

Degree of contraction

Management

Pelvic inlet contraction

Minor or moderately contracted pelvis
  • Induction of Labour can be done 2-3 weeks before EDD (Estimated delivery date).
  • A trial of labour can be done if EDD has arrived failure, which can lead to a cesarean section.

Moderately contracted pelvis with contraction of the mid pelvis or outlet or any high-risk factors (Diabetes, heart disease, tuberculosis).

Elective cesarean section

Midpelvis or Outlet contraction

Mild to moderate contraction
  • Trial of labour can be done, accompanied by augmentation of labour with Oxytocin, deep episiotomy and use of forceps/ventouse.
  • If the trial fails, i.e. no dilatation of cervix or descent of fetus for 2 hours in the active phase of labour, cesarean section can be done.

Severe contraction

Cesarean section can be done.

questions.text: What is the best method of pelvimetry assessment of the pelvis?

A 30 year old female patient is in labour, the doctor needs to determine if any contractions at the pelvic brim might impede the baby's passage. To do this, she evaluates specific pelvic measurements. Which of the following salient features is noted to detect pelvic contraction at the brim?
questions.explanation:
Brim

Midpelvis

Outlet
  • Diagonal conjugate
  • Posterior surface of the symphysis pubis
  • Iliopectineal line
  • Sacrosciatic notch
  • Sacrum
  • Ischial spines
  • Interspinous diameter
  • Sacrosciatic notch
  • Sidewalls
  • Sidewalls
  • Sacrococcygeal joint
  • Subpubic arch
  • Subpubic angle
  • Transverse diameter

questions.text: A 30 year old primigravida at 38 weeks gestation presents for a routine check-up. Concerned about difficult labour due to pelvic fractures, her obstetrician orders an X-ray pelvimetry. Which of the following can be assessed using X-ray pelvimetry?

options.label: C
options.text: Size and shape of the pelvis

questions.correct_answer: C. Size and shape of the pelvis

questions.text: Which of the following findings indicates a contracted pelvis at the midpelvic level?

options.label: B
options.text: Greatest transverse diameter at the pelvic brim measuring 11 cm

options.label: C
options.text: The sum of the interischial spinous and posterior sagittal diameters measuring 12.5 cm

questions.correct_answer: C. The sum of the interischial spinous and posterior sagittal diameters measuring 12.5 cm
questions.explanation:
True Pelvis

Criteria to diagnose contracted pelvis

Pelvic inlet

Obstetric conjugate <10 cm

  • Greatest transverse diameter <12 cm
  • Diagonal conjugate <11 cm

Midpelvis

The sum of the interischial spinous and posterior sagittal diameters measuring 13 cm.

Pelvic outlet

An interischial tuberous diameter of 8 cm indicates contraction.
